Award.AbstractNarration:
This project extends the frontier of search theory to shed light on three economic problems. The first asks how we should expect rejection rates at colleges to vary with caliber, and inquires whether they are informative measures of excellence. Preliminary research suggests that rejection rates might be reverse quality measures at the very best colleges. The second application explores the economics of optimal liquidation, such as transpired with the Resolution Trust Corporation in the 1990s or prior to the famous bankruptcy of Lehman-Brothers in 2008. Early work reveals, among other things, how an optimal selling strategy proceeds far more slowly at lower interest rates, formalizing an insight publicized by Alan Greenspan. The third develops a theoretical analysis of the economics of web search, such as occurs in web sites like Amazon; among early findings are that the seller need not find it most profitable to make a maximally informative search engine.

The project pursues two dynamic programming projects in search theory, and one directed search model. The first project incorporates insights from auction theory into a directed search problem that is motivated by the journal submission and college application processes. As the rank of the journal or college rises, its standards rise and its applicants improve. But it is not obvious that rejection rates must rise and in fact, with complete information, early results suggest that they do not. The two dynamic programming exercises explore two inherently nonstationary search models. The first is how does one optimally unwind a large position in an asset when facing periodic arrivals of buyers willing to buy portion at a specified price. Among many key results, most important is the "decreasing returns to optionality" that the value function is concave in the position - but the marginal value is convex. The second dynamic programming exercise explores how one optimally searches among many ranked options. This arises in web search, and this model is tractable enough to produce many novel usable comparative statics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The economic parable of the market that we teach, with crossing supply and demand curves, is overly simplistic. The project was an exploration of the richer world we live in, exploring how search frictions impede trade and impact who trades with whom and how fast.

The first subproject is now published under the revised title “Search at the Margin”, with my former advisee Tono Carrasco. Search theory has for half a century explored how best to buy or sell a single good when opportunities are scarce. This paper expands the search program to allow for search for many items. This often arises, for instance, when airlines try to sell out seats on a plane, or when entertainment event seats are sold. Search theory explains how one should optimally trade off the bird in the hand for two in the future bush. For every potential sale must smartly account for optionality – the expected gains in the future over the current option. We showed how to do this for many units, crucially finding that optionality suffers from diminishing returns in the number of units. This arises because marginal units can only be sold with delay. This additional cost forces reservation prices down. This project derives a tractable new framework for this problem, and characterizes how this decline responds to economic forces, and how it impacts prices.

The second subproject is now nearly done, under the revised title "Accept this Paper", with Andrea Wilson at Georgetown. This was motivated by the common way that colleges and journals are ranked by so-called selectivity – namely, their rejection rates. While it seems superficially a wise boast that college A rejects more applicants than college B, and so must surely be better, this logic does ignore the obvious fact that better colleges have better applicants. We devise an equilibrium model of this two stage application procedure of the simpler game played by authors sending papers to journal applications.

We set up a benchmark static model in which journals are competitive and the evaluation noise obeys a standard monotone hazard rate condition. Authors want to maximize the expected journal caliber that accepts them. When authors know their papers’ qualities, we show that the rejection rate logically cannot always increase in caliber. Rather, it must rise and then eventually fall. In other words, the selectivity criterion moves inversely to caliber among the elite journals, and is an unwise quality measure. When authors are only imperfectly informed of their paper quality, then the model is richer, and the conclusions require sophisticated logic. But the takeout remains roughly the same – that provided authors have a sufficiently precise signal of their paper’s quality, the rejection rate is still hump-shaped, and falls for the most elite journals. Further, we find how rejection itself becomes more likely with more evaluation noise.

The third subproject, "Optimal Sequential Search Among Alternatives", is under revision. It is joint with Michael Choi, a former advisee and now assistant professor at UC-Irvine. It also advances the search agenda, but now in a different direction. For search theory only offers sharp conclusions in idealized stationary environments, when no one ever recalls an old option, and the but the search does not grow more desperate with the passage of time. But in the web search world, we face presorted options – the most promising first, then the next, and so on. In this search world,  we use statistical theory to offer predictions for recall rates and stopping rates. We also solve a problem open for almost half a century of what leads individuals to search longer.
